title: Scalars and vectors - magnitude of sum

content.question: Vectors <math alttext="vector M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mover><mi>M</mi><mo>→</mo></mover></math> and <math alttext="vector N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mover><mi>N</mi><mo>→</mo></mover></math> are parallel to the <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi></math>-axis. Let <math alttext="a equals, the absolute value of vector M plus vector N, end absolute value" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>|</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>M</mi><mo>→</mo></mover><mo>+</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>N</mi><mo>→</mo></mover><mo>|</mo></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="b equals the absolute value of vector M, end absolute value, plus the absolute value of vector N, end absolute value" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>|</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>M</mi><mo>→</mo></mover><mo>|</mo><mo>+</mo><mo>|</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>N</mi><mo>→</mo></mover><mo>|</mo></mstyle></math>. A student claims that is possible that <math alttext="a is less than b" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>a</mi><mo><</mo><mi>b</mi></math>. Which of the following indicates whether the claim is correct and provides a valid justification?

choices.label: The claim is correct, because the magnitude of the sum of two vectors is always less than the sum of the magnitudes of the vectors.

The claim is correct, because the vectors <math alttext="vector M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mover accent="true"><mi>M</mi><mo>→</mo></mover></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="vector N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mover accent="true"><mi>N</mi><mo>→</mo></mover></mstyle></math> could be in opposite directions.

The claim is incorrect, because the values of <math alttext="a" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>a</mi></math> and <math alttext="b" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>b</mi></math> must be equal since the vectors <math alttext="vector M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mover accent="true"><mi>M</mi><mo>→</mo></mover></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="vector N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mover accent="true"><mi>N</mi><mo>→</mo></mover></mstyle></math> are parallel.

The claim is incorrect, because the values of <math alttext="a" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>a</mi></math> and <math alttext="b" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>b</mi></math> must be equal since the magnitude of a vector sum must equal the sum of the individual vector magnitudes.
